I mean, it's sort of segregating us, relegating us to a certain area. I realize that that's a big part of TV, where sports are segregated to sports, chick flicks to the chick flicks channel, Oprah, Dr. Phil, and Montel all to their channel etc, but I just can't help feel that this doesn't do homosexuals any good to have us apart like that. 
 What do you all think?

 I agree with you. My impression would be that this would contribute to "out of sight, out of mind" feeling in regards to homosexual issues. It would also contribute to those who resent the increase of programs with gay characters or gay themes since homosexuals would, in essence, have their own channel for this. If a channel were to exist, I would have to sympathize with those who resent more mainstream gay programs since gays would indeed have their own channel for such things, and representation in the mainstream would no longer have the moral weight it currently has.
 
 It would also provide an excuse to remove such programs from mainstream networks with less of a push for equal treatment, since a gay channel could and would be deemed "more appropriate" for such programs. Segregation is hardly ever the answer.

 I don't understand this at all. 
 
 Gay people have been complaining for years about the lack of accurate portrayals of GLBT people on tv. The response has been poor. So some decide to create a channel geared towards us and people think it's a bad idea? 
 
 People are going to watch whatever they want and flip past whatever they don't want to. What, exactly, is bad or segregationist about creating channels geared towards different markets?
Yeah, I mean, if there can be a Comedy Channel, it's discrimination not to have a Humorless Channel, right? And what's with this Animal Planet? I demand a Human Planet channel! emoticon_rolleyes
I just added the UWB Network to MY cable lineup--the UnderWater Basketweaving channel. Edgy stuff!!! :p

Gay people have been complaining for years about the lack of accurate portrayals of GLBT people on tv. The response has been poor. So some decide to create a channel geared towards us and people think it's a bad idea?

 
 No, not bad. Counterproductive (depending on your goal). It certainly will give positive portrayals of gay people to gay people, which is certainly a worthy goal. However, if integration into everyday society is your goal then this is counterproductive. 
 
 

 People are going to watch whatever they want and flip past whatever they don't want to. What, exactly, is bad or segregationist about creating channels geared towards different markets?

 
 This isn't simply separate markets, which could be accomplished with different programming. This is removing the gay audience, and thus programming directed at gay people, from mainstream programming (to an extent). Think of it as serving different meals at dinner versus serving different meals in different rooms for dinner. 
 
 I would expect those who complain about programming directed at gays to want a channel like this to attract gay audiences away from mainstream programming.
 
 Just my opinion, of course

Then be prepared for it's continued absence from mainstream programming, since there will be no incentive to have such positive portrayals now that gay people have their own channel for such things.

 
 
 Sadly, you could be right. Typically gays in the media have always been potrayed as Negative or troubled or psycho sex maniacs, or weak and distressed and timid. XXXXX as Folk came along and changed some of that but also potrayed more of the same old same ole. Don't get me wrong I love QAF, but I also understand that it isn't what gays are really like. The deal is that gays, as they really are, aren't that interesting. Certainly not enough to sell as entertainment. God knows reality TV about my partner and I would put you to sleep faster than Ambien. 
 
 BUT, as a gay man, I do get so tired of seeing every gay person on TV as evil, sinister, or weak and in distress. None of my circle of friends are like that at all. We have boring lives. Most of my friends have long term relationships (being 5 to 30 years). We do yard work, house stuff, some are raising kids....it is all pretty mundane, but that doesn't catch interest or sell. I get that!
 
 I guess my point is, TV isn't the best representation of life, only a small part of it.

Logo, could help increase demand for programming with gay themes. The larger, main networks may then be motivated to increase their own gay programming, to get as much of that market as they can.
 
 The same argument could be used in support of BET, on the other thread. 
 
 Think about what happened with gay bookstores. The main bookstore chains started to carry the same books as the smaller gay bookstores became successful, and the gay bookstores built-up demand. Now the small gay bookstores are struggling to survive against the corporate giants.

Logo, could help increase demand for programming with gay themes. The larger, main networks may then be motivated to increase their own gay programming, to get as much of that market as they can.
 
 The same argument could be used in support of BET, on the other thread.

 
 Perhaps, but I think not, unless the ratings for this new station go through the roof. Keep in mind that networks are businesses and straight people comprise the vast majority of the population. They would have to balance alienating straight people (for straight people want to identify with characters just as gay people do) with attracting the gay audience. It is my belief that they would turn somewhat or completely away from gay themes in preference to a more broadly appealing programming.
 
 The same argument could indeed be used for BET, since both work to separate two groups instead of integrating them. This works against the goal of equal representation in mainstream life, and everyday society. It creates the impression that the two groups do not belong together, imo.
 
 

 Think about what happened with gay bookstores. The main bookstore chains started to carry the same books as the smaller gay bookstores became successful, and the gay bookstores built-up demand. Now the small gay bookstores are struggling to survive against the corporate giants.

 
 Except in our case, the big bookstores already had the books. Unless the smaller stores are wildly successful, the big bookstores won't alienate their other customers to cater to the gay crowd more than they already are. It's a balancing act.

The whole idea of niche programming is to appeal to very small audiences. That's why it's called niche. (Duh!)
 
 It's meant to appeal to groups who have interests not served by the mainstream media, usually for economic reasons Gardening, pets, latino culture, gay culture, Russian culture, video games, fundamentalist religion... you name it.
 
 The idea that some people would view such programming with resentment because they're not in that particular niche, and make these petulant "then why shouldn't we have an everything-that-is-not-that-niche" reactions to them I find disturbing. It certainly says much more about them than the people who would enjoy such programming, and what it says is not pretty.

It's the same thing you see with these people who react to gay pride parades by saying "Then why can't we have a straight pride parade?" Well, in the first place, they probably can, if they can get the permit and enough people together for it. But the motivation for having the parade would be prejudicial resentment, not an equivalent demonstration of self-respect and lack of shame. (It's that positive sense that the word Pride is used, though they conveniently like to think that it's the "arrogant, boastful" sense.) Straights aren't ashamed of being straight, and no one's trying to make them be, or ever has. Consequently, there's no deep-seated group need to assert that they are okay with themselves being heterosexual. Such a parade would be purely anti-gay, a negative reaction rather than any kind of positive statement, a childish "so there!"
 
 Why should anyone care whether there's a TV channel devoted to something they personally don't relate to or may even dislike? I personally am revolted by the programming on Pat Robertson's channel. So what? If I suggested he shouldn't have such a channel without an equivalent Robertson-free channel, you'd be right in thinking me ridiculous. I don't have to watch the frigging thing, but obviously many like to. There's no lack of programming I can choose to watch without the likelihood of running into Robertson or his dangerously screwball opinions, so why should I resent the fact that he has a channel of his own? 
 
 If having a channel with programming geared towards a minority culture or interest group stirs resentment and demands for equal time by those whose majority culture or interests have always been and continue to be thoroughly well-represented in the media, then I say the problem is with the people doing the resenting--who seriously need to get over it.

Integration into society will be dependent on more gay people being open and honest with their lives. Entertainment on these gay-friendly channels will be more reflective of that than mainstream programming, IMO. If there is a problem with the mere existence of these channels by people, then there is an issue with homophobia on the part of those individuals.

 
 Integration into society depends more on society's acceptance than gay people being open with themselves. Separating gay programming will work counter to this goal, because it will no longer expose the public to gay people via mainstream programming. This, in turn, will make being gay something strange and unnatural to a whole new generation because they would never have been exposed to it. Out of sight out of mind, tonybrown74.
 
 If gay people fight for more and more positive representation in mainstream channels as well, this will likely cause resentment because gay people already have their own channel for such programs. This could and would be different than simple homophobia, and likely even those who are tolerant now would feel resentment toward this. It could and likely would be viewed as greedy and a case of "wanting your cake and eating it too".
 
 

 By this reasoning, your solution seems to be creating one big mega channel, since the creation of a cable station based on a niche market will always alienate someone.

 
 No, my solution would be one of two things: Have your channel and be happy with it, but realize that it will have an effect on the perception of gay people; or try for more and better integration into everyday society, which is accomplished better by coexistence rather than segregation. Not both.

 The idea that some people would view such programming with resentment because they're not in that particular niche, and make these petulant "then why shouldn't we have an everything-that-is-not-that-niche" reactions to them I find disturbing. It certainly says much more about them than the people who would enjoy such programming, and what it says is not pretty.
 

 
 I'll try to put it another way with something that everyone can understand: Porn.
 
 A porn store has gay porn to cater to gay men (women as well, but men consume the vast majority of porn so I will simplify it to simply men). A porn store has "straight" porn (which covers a wide variety of fetishes) to cater to straight men. The gay section is likely to be smaller and have less variety since the majority of people consuming porn are straight men.
 
 Now. You, as a gay man (or just an entrepreneur), open a separate gay porn store, intending to have more variety that the general porn store lacked. Gay men will likely visit the gay porn store, as intended, for their porn needs instead of the general porn store. Therefore, the likely result in the general porn store is that the gay section will get smaller or disappear entirely. The general porn store is not likely to expand his selection to compete because he has to balance his straight customers, who comprise the vast majority of his business, with attracting gay customers who likely won't visit his store anyway with his limited selection.
 
 He will more likely, imo, turn his energies and funds to keeping his straight customers happier than alienating them by expanding the gay porn collection. It is not that the straight customers have a moral issue with gay porn, but more gay porn means less straight porn.
 
 Now, if your goal is just to have a service to the gay community then there is no problem. If your goal is to have more representation in the general porn store, despite having the smaller gay porn store for your needs, you will cause resentment among the straight men who want straight porn. This is not because they hate gay men, but because gay men have their own store for such things and so the feeling would be that gay men want their cake and to eat it too. Figuratively speaking, of course. Needless to say, gay porn will become more taboo because it is not seen as often in the general porn store, so it is seen as less "normal" by the general porn shopper.
 
 This isn't a perfect analogy, but I believe the concepts are sound. Not everything is homophobia or racism.
